results.title: The Flight of the snows
results.creator_credit: Jean-Louis Frund, Donald Duprey, International Cinemedia Centre Ltd and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The snow goose is a tightly scheduled bird. It winters in the United States, flies 4,000 kilometres to breed and raise a family in the high Arctic, and returns before the frost sets in. This film documents the formation-flying, feeding habits, rearing of young and lifestyle of the great snow goose. Written by Joseph Koenig; music by James Solkin; voice and narration by Bud Knapp.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jean-Louis Frund, Donald Duprey, International Cinemedia Centre Ltd and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Studio system
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Pitkethly, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “American cinema”.
This program surveys Hollywood’s industrial past during the era of contract players and directors, studio police forces and colourful movie moguls. It also overviews the modern film-making environment with studio heads Michael Eisner, Howard Koch and others. Paramount Pictures, one of the oldest and most successful of the Hollywood studios, serves as a case study.

results.title: The Final academy documents 1962/63
results.brief_description: Contains archival film footage of William S. Burroughs and Brion Gysin, filmed by the late Anthony Balch in 1962-1963. Includes “Ghosts at Number 9” and the classic film “Towers Open Fire”.

results.title: Film in the television age
results.creator_credit: Elizabeth Foster, Alain Klarer, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “American cinema”.
Television arrived in American homes just as the Hollywood studio system was collasping. As the new medium took hold, so did a new era in motion picture entertainment. Renown directors, film scholars and actors trace the influence of each medium upon the other; from the live and fresh dramas of the Golden Age of Television and the growth of Hollywood spectacles to the modern day megalithic entertainment industry.

results.title: The Film of the Royal Ballet
results.creator_credit: Paul Czinner, Poetic Films and Royal Opera House Covent Garden
results.brief_description: Starring Margot Fonteyn, the great Prima Ballerina, in the principal female roles and Michael Somes in the lead male roles, this film showcases three of ballets’ most moving performances. Three tragic tales of doomed love filmed during performances of the Corps De Ballet of the Royal Opera House. Director of Ballet is Dame Ninette De Valois. Music is performed by the Covent Garden Orchestra. The first is Piotr Tchaikovsky’s brilliant “Swan Lake, Act II” which depicts the powerful meeting of the hunter, Prince Siegfried, and the prey, a graceful swan who transforms into a beautiful girl. The second performance is of Igor Stravinsky’s “The firebird”, the story of a travelling prince who captures a fantastical firebird who bargains her way to freedom by giving him one of her magic feathers. The third performance is of Hans Werner Henze’s “Ondine”, the story of Palemon, who is torn between his love of Berta and a water-sprite, Ondine.

results.title: Film noir
results.creator_credit: Jeffrey Schon, Sasha Alpert, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “American cinema”.
These cynical and pessimistic films from the 1930’s and 1940’s touched a raw nerve in Americans. Historians link the genre’s overriding paranoia to Cold War related angst over the nuclear threat and the Hollywood blacklist. Additionally, a cinematographer demonstrates the creation of lighting which gives these films their peculiar look thus emphasising the themes of corruption and urban decay.

results.title: The Field
results.creator_credit: Jim Sheridan, Noel Pearson and Granada Television International
results.brief_description: Bull McCabe (Richard Harris) and his son Tadgh (Sean Bean) have sacrificed their lives for the sake of turning the land of a local widower into a successful field but when she says she wants to sell to the highest bidder at public auction, there is no guarantee that the McCabe’s history with the land will guarantee future ownership. Bull’s biggest fear that the field will be taken over by an outsider becomes a reality when “The American” (Tom Berenger) arrives in their small Irish town. Without any cash or other means at their disposal, the only resistance the McCabes can offer is violence, continuing a trend of tragedy that has dogged the family for years. Brenda Fricker co-stars as Bull’s silent and long suffering wife, John Hurt as the simpleton “Bird”. Set in Ireland in the 1930s and based on the play “The Field” by John B. Keane.

results.title: American cinema
results.creator_credit: Greg Martinelli, Molly Ornati, Rita Mate, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description: A 13 part series examining the cinema industry. Producers, directors, actors, cinematographers and Hollywood stars reveal insights into the business of making motion pictures. John Lithgow introduces each episode which encompasses a theme and examines it in detail with clips from some of the world’s renown films.

results.title: The Ferrara poems
results.creator_credit: Jenny Robertson, Australian Film Commission and S A Department for the Arts
results.brief_description: Two Australian travellers Karl (Michael Snelling) and Giselle (Kerin Murray) meet up with friends at a cafe in Italy for coffee and discuss their cultural experiences and observations of the country. A trip is planned and the group sets off together on another sight-seeing adventure. A postmodernist film essay exploring the structure of storytelling through the deliberate raw use of cinematic and film making devices (making those devices transparent). A film about foreigners, film making and foreign processes. Cast also includes: Ken Bolton, Mark Thomson and Tish Banks. Narrator: Richard Grayson.

results.title: The Flight of dragons
results.creator_credit: Arthur Rankin Jnr, Jules Bass and Rankin-Bass Productions
results.brief_description: Journey back to a magical time when the skies were filled with dragons in this feature-length animated version of Peter Dickinson’s acclaimed book. The tale is of the sinister Red Wizard Ommadon (James Earl Jones), who threatens to destroy nature. The world’s only hope is a man of science and magic from the future named Peter (John Ritter), snatched from the 20th century by the Green Wizard Carolinus (Harry Morgan) to capture Ommadon’s Red crown and thus take away his powers. Peter, accompanied by a fire-breathing dragon, an outlaw elf and a noble knight, applies modern-day logic to battling ancient evil.

description_for_label: Journey back to a magical time when the skies were filled with dragons in this feature-length animated version of Peter Dickinson’s acclaimed book. The tale is of the sinister Red Wizard Ommadon (James Earl Jones), who threatens to destroy nature. The world’s only hope is a man of science and magic from the future named Peter (John Ritter), snatched from the 20th century by the Green Wizard Carolinus (Harry Morgan) to capture Ommadon’s Red crown and thus take away his powers. Peter, accompanied by a fire-breathing dragon, an outlaw elf and a noble knight, applies modern-day logic to battling ancient evil.
